description: The linear-gradient() and radial-gradient() CSS functions and their repeating counterparts create backgrounds that progress smoothly between multiple colors.
description_html: The linear-gradient() and radial-gradient() CSS functions and their repeating counterparts create backgrounds that progress smoothly between multiple colors.
name: Gradients

chrome.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

chrome_android.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

firefox.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -moz.

firefox_android.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -moz.

oculus.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

opera.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -o.

opera_android.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

safari.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

safari_ios.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

webview_android.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

webview_ios.notes: Some versions support only experimental gradients prefixed with -webkit.

notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Since Firefox for Android 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 5.5 through 9.0 supported gradients via a proprietary filter: -ms-filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Gradient().

opera.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

opera_android.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

Safari on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

WebView on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

compat.description: Gradients applied to pre-multiplied color space (prevents grays from appearing in gradients with transparency)

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

firefox_android.notes: Since Firefox for Android 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 5.5 through 9.0 supported gradients via a proprietary filter: -ms-filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Gradient().

safari.notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

safari_ios.notes: Safari on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

webview_ios.notes: WebView on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

compat.description: Gradients applied to pre-multiplied color space (prevents grays from appearing in gradients with transparency)

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.

notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.

notes: Since Firefox for Android 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 5.5 through 9.0 supported gradients via a proprietary filter: -ms-filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Gradient().

opera.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

opera_android.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in repeating-linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

Safari on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in repeating-linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

WebView on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in repeating-linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

safari.notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

safari_ios.notes: Safari on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

webview_ios.notes: WebView on iOS 3.2 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox for Android 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
